          "headline": "Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued September 3 at 5:35PM CDT until September 3 at 6:00PM CDT by NWS Topeka KS",
          "description": "At 534 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Abilene, moving\nsoutheast at 25 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Golf ball size hail and 60 mph wind gusts.\n\nSOURCE...Trained weather spotters. At 5:29 PM, quarter size hail was\nreported 3 miles WNW of Abilene.\n\nIMPACT...People and animals outdoors will be injured. Expect hail\ndamage to roofs, siding, windows, and vehicles. Expect wind\ndamage to roofs, siding, and trees.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nAbilene, Solomon, and Enterprise.\n\nThis includes Interstate 70 between mile markers 267 and 283.",

          "event": "Flood Advisory",
          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS San Diego CA",
          "headline": "Flood Advisory issued September 3 at 3:34PM PDT until September 3 at 6:32PM PDT by NWS San Diego CA",
          "description": "* WHAT...Small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is\nexpected.\n\n* WHERE...A portion of Southwest California, including the following\ncounty, San Diego, just north of Julian.\n\n* WHEN...Until 632 PM PDT.\n\n* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 333 PM PDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to\nthunderstorms. This will cause small stream flooding.\n- Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are expected over\nthe area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding.\n- Some locations that will experience flooding include...\nJulian, Hwy 78 Between Banner And S2, Hwy S2 Between Hwy 79\nAnd Hwy 78, Hwy 79 Between Santa Ysabel And Warner Springs,\nRanchita, Warner Springs, Hwy 79 Between Julian And Lake\nCuyamaca, Hwy 78 Between Ramona And Santa Ysabel, Santa\nYsabel Indian Reservation and Santa Ysabel.\n- https://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
          "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nBe aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads.",
          "response": "Avoid",

            ],

          "senderName": "NWS Las Vegas NV",
          "headline": "Flood Advisory issued September 3 at 3:28PM PDT until September 3 at 5:45PM PDT by NWS Las Vegas NV",
          "description": "* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.\n\n* WHERE...A portion of northwest Arizona, including the following\ncounty, Mohave. This includes portions of the Grand Canyon\nParashant National Monument.\n\n* WHEN...Until 545 PM MST.\n\n* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.\nRises in small streams and normally dry washes.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 328 PM MST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to\nthunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin\nshortly in the advisory area. Between 0.5 and 1 inch of rain\nhas fallen. Areas of runoff will likely continue through late\nthis afternoon.\n- Some locations that will experience flooding include...\nmainly rural areas of North Central Mohave County\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",

          "headline": "Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued September 3 at 5:24PM CDT until September 3 at 6:15PM CDT by NWS Topeka KS",
          "description": "SVRTOP\n\nThe National Weather Service in Topeka has issued a\n\n* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...\nSoutheastern Wabaunsee County in east central Kansas...\nNorthwestern Osage County in east central Kansas...\nNortheastern Lyon County in east central Kansas...\n\n* Until 615 PM CDT.\n\n* At 524 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Harveyville,\nmoving southeast at 15 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Ping pong ball size hail and 60 mph wind gusts.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...People and animals outdoors will be injured. Expect hail\ndamage to roofs, siding, windows, and vehicles. Expect\nwind damage to roofs, siding, and trees.\n\n* Locations impacted include...\nBurlingame, Scranton, and Harveyville.\n\nThis includes Kansas Turnpike between mile markers 149 and 161.",
          "instruction": "Prepare immediately for large hail and damaging winds. People outside\nshould move immediately to shelter inside a strong building. Stay\naway from windows.",

          "headline": "Flood Advisory issued September 3 at 2:15PM AKDT until September 4 at 4:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK",
          "description": "* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.\n\n* WHERE...Koyukuk River near Allakaket.\n\n* WHEN...Until 400 PM AKDT Thursday.\n\n* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- As of Wednesday afternoon, there have been reports of some\nlow lying roads remaining inundated.\n\n- River gauges in the area are showing decreasing water levels\nalong the Koyukuk, including in Allakaket.           "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Seattle WA",
          "headline": "Red Flag Warning issued September 3 at 3:05PM PDT until September 4 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Seattle WA",
          "description": "* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 658 West Slopes of the North\nCascades Generally above 1500 Feet and Fire Weather Zone 659\nWest Slopes of the Central Cascades Generally above 1500 Feet\nnorth of Gifford Pinchot National Forest.\n\n* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 20 percent.\n\n* TEMPERATURES...Up to 85.\n\n* STABILITY...Unstable conditions can be expected.\n\n* IMPACTS...A dry and unstable air mass with warm temperatures\ncan contribute to active fire behavior. In western Washington,\nsignificant growth on existing fires takes place under such\nconditions. If a fire were to begin, air quality may diminish\nin the surrounding area.",
          "instruction": "A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions\nare either imminent or occurring now. Any fires that develop will\nlikely spread quickly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.",

          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Birmingham AL",
          "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued September 3 at 5:01PM CDT by NWS Birmingham AL",
          "description": "At 501 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a cluster of strong\nthunderstorms near Chickasaw State Park, or 8 miles southeast of\nDemopolis, moving east at 15 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and pea size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\nunsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is\npossible.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nUniontown, Faunsdale, Dayton, Chickasaw State Park, Perry County\nCorrectional Center, Old Spring Hill, and Carleys.",
          "instruction": "If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building.\n\nTorrential rainfall is also occurring with this storm and may lead to\nlocalized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded\nroadways.\n\nFrequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.\nLightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe\nshelter inside a building or vehicle.",

          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Flagstaff AZ",
          "headline": "Flood Advisory issued September 3 at 3:01PM MST until September 3 at 4:15PM MST by NWS Flagstaff AZ",
          "description": "* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected along\nLake Mary Road, near Mormon Lake.\n\n* WHERE...A portion of north central Arizona, including the\nfollowing county, Coconino.\n\n* WHEN...Until 415 PM MST.\n\n* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in creeks and normally dry washes is\nimminent or occurring.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 300 PM MST, Doppler radar indicated light rain still\nfalling in the area. As much as 3 inches pf rain may have\nfallen just east of Mormon Lake. Minor flooding is likely\nongoing in the advisory area.\n- This includes the following creeks, washes and rivers...\nYoungs Canyon, Yellow Jacket Canyon, Anderson Canyon, Padre\nCanyon, Yaeger Canyon and Walnut Creek.\n- Some locations that will experience flooding include...\nAshurst Lake, Perry Lake, Boot Lake, Mud Lake, Lakeview,\nMormon Lake and Upper Lake Mary.\n- This includes the following recreation areas and\ncampgrounds...\nDairy Springs Campground, Ashurst Lake Campgrounds, Pine\nGrove Campground, Forked Pine Campground and Dairy Springs\nCampground.\n- Additional information is available at weather.gov/flagstaff.",
          "instruction": "Be aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads.\n\nLow water crossings will become dangerous in heavy rain. Do not\nattempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route.",
          "response": "Avoid",
          "parameters": {
            "AWIPSidentifier": [
              "FLSFGZ"
            ],

          "event": "Air Quality Alert",
          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Portland OR",
          "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued September 3 at 2:31PM PDT by NWS Portland OR",
          "description": "The Lane Regional Air Protection Agency has continued an Air\nQuality Advisory, which is IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM PDT THURSDAY.\n\nAn Air Quality Advisory for Smoke remains in effect. Wildfires\nburning in the region combined with forecasted conditions will\ncause air quality to reach unhealthy levels at times through Thursday\nevening.\n\nPollutants in smoke can cause burning eyes, runny nose, aggravate\nheart and lung diseases, and aggravate other serious health\nproblems. Limit outdoor activities and keep children indoors if it\nis smoky. Please follow medical advice if you have a heart or lung\ncondition.\n\nMore information about air quality can be found at:\nwww.lrapa.org",
          "instruction": null,
          "response": "Monitor",
          "parameters": {

          "event": "Heat Advisory",
          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Portland OR",
          "headline": "Heat Advisory issued September 3 at 2:30PM PDT until September 4 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR",
          "description": "* WHAT...Afternoon high temperatures in the mid to upper 90s and\novernight low temperatures in the mid 60s to lower 70s expected.\n\n* WHERE...Western and Central Columbia River Gorge and the Hood\nRiver Valley.\n\n* WHEN...Until 8 PM PDT Thursday.\n\n* IMPACTS...Hot temperatures may cause heat illnesses.",
          "instruction": "Drink plenty of fluids, stay in a cool place during the heat of the\nday, stay out of the sunshine, and check up on relatives and\nneighbors. For those without air conditioning, use fans to keep air\nmoving. Keeps windows closed during the day and open at night,\nunless air quality is degraded due to wildfire smoke.\n\nTake extra precautions when outside. Wear lightweight and loose\nfitting clothing. Try to limit strenuous activities to early morning\nor evening. Take action when you see symptoms of heat exhaustion and\nheat stroke.\n\nDo not leave young children and pets in unattended vehicles. Car\ninteriors will reach lethal temperatures in a matter of minutes.",
          "response": "Execute",
          "parameters": {

              "NPWPQR"
            ],

          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Jackson MS",
          "headline": "Flash Flood Warning issued September 3 at 4:14PM CDT until September 3 at 7:15PM CDT by NWS Jackson MS",
          "description": "FFWJAN\n\nThe National Weather Service in Jackson has issued a\n\n* Flash Flood Warning for...\nSouthern Kemper County in east central Mississippi...\n\n* Until 715 PM CDT.\n\n* At 414 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing\nheavy rain across the warned area. Between 2 and 5 inches of rain\nhave fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are\npossible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected\nto begin shortly.\n\nHAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.\n\nSOURCE...Radar.\n\nIMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban\nareas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as\nother poor drainage and low-lying areas.\n\n* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include...\nPorterville, Blackwater, Liberty, Prismatic, Damascus and Tamola.",
          "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.",
          "response": "Avoid",
          "parameters": {

          "event": "Heat Advisory",
          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Seattle WA",
          "headline": "Heat Advisory issued September 3 at 2:08PM PDT until September 4 at 5:00PM PDT by NWS Seattle WA",
          "description": "* WHAT...Hot conditions with high temperatures ranging from the mid\n80s to the lower 90s and low temperatures in the 60s. This will\npose a moderate to locally major risk of heat-related illness.\n\n* WHERE...Foothills and Valleys of the North Cascades, Foothills and\nValleys of Central King County, Foothills and Valleys of Pierce\nand Southern King Counties, Foothills and Valleys of Snohomish and\nNorthern King Counties, and Foothills and Valleys of Thurston and\nLewis Counties.\n\n* WHEN...Until 5 PM PDT Thursday.\n\n* IMPACTS...Heat will significantly increase the risk of\nheat-related illnesses for those who are sensitive to heat,\nespecially those without effective cooling or adequate hydration.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The hottest temperatures will primarily be\nfocused in the Cascade valleys this afternoon and Thursday, where\ntemperatures in the mid 90s can be expected. The overnight lows\nwill remain very warm and provide little to no relief, especially\nin locations such as Packwood, Marblemount, and Darrington.",
          "instruction": "Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out of\nthe sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young children and\npets should never be left unattended in vehicles under any\ncircumstances.\n\nTake extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When\npossible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or\nevening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat\nstroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when possible.\nTo reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational Safety and\nHealth Administration recommends scheduling frequent rest breaks in\nshaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone overcome by heat\nshould be moved to a cool and shaded location. Heat stroke is an\nemergency! Call 9 1 1.\n\nFor sheltering information and other human services in your area,\ndial 2 1 1 during business hours or visit wa211.org anytime.",
          "response": "Execute",
          "parameters": {
            "AWIPSidentifier": [
              "NPWSEW"
            ],
            "WMOidentifier": [
              "WWUS76 KSEW 032108"
            ],
            "NWSheadline": [
              "HEAT ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 PM PDT THURSDAY"
            ],
            "BLOCKCHANNEL": [
              "EAS",
              "NWEM",
              "CMAS"
            ],

          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Flagstaff AZ",
          "headline": "Flash Flood Warning issued September 3 at 2:01PM MST until September 3 at 5:00PM MST by NWS Flagstaff AZ",
          "description": "FFWFGZ\n\nThe National Weather Service in Flagstaff has issued a\n\n* Flash Flood Warning for...\nNavajo County in north central Arizona...\n\n* Until 600 PM MDT.\n\n* At 301 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing\nheavy rain near Kayenta and into portions of Monument Valley.\nFlash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.\n\nHAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms\nproducing flash flooding.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams,\nnormally dry washes, urban areas, highways, streets\nand underpasses.\n\n* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include...\nKayenta, Kayenta Airport, Navajo National Monument, Tsegi and Ruin\nArch.\n\nThis includes the following highways...\nHighway 160 between mile markers 382 and 405.\nHighway 163 between mile markers 394 and 411.\n\nThis includes the following creeks, washes and rivers...\nParrish Creek, Capitan Wash, El, Narrow Canyon Wash, Tyende Creek,\nCutfoot Wash, Moenkopi Wash, Nokai Creek, Tsegi Canyon and Laguna\nCreek.",
          "instruction": "Flooding of washes and creeks will occur, some dirt roads will\nbecome muddy and impassable. Paved roads and underpasses could\nbecome flooded as well.",
          "response": "Avoid",
          "parameters": {

              "FFWFGZ"
            ],
            "WMOidentifier": [
              "WGUS55 KFGZ 032101"
            ],

          "headline": "Red Flag Warning issued September 3 at 1:52PM PDT until September 4 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Spokane WA",
          "description": "* Affected Area: Okanogan Highlands and Kettle Mountains (Zone\n699), Selkirk Mountains of Northeast Washington (Zone 700),\nFoothills of Northeast Washington (Zone 701) and Colville\nReservation (Zone 702).\n\n* Winds: Terrain driven winds 2 to 5 mph becoming northwest to\nnorth overnight 3 to 7 mph.\n\n* Relative Humidities: Minimum 10 to 18 percent. Humidity\nrecoveries on midslopes within thermal belts of 25 to 35\npercent.\n\n* Temperatures: 97 to 103 valleys. 85 to 90 mountains.\n\n* Impacts: Hot, dry, unstable conditions will lead to the\npotential for rapid fire growth on new or existing fires.",
          "instruction": "A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions\nare either occurring now....or will shortly. A combination of\nstrong winds...low relative humidity...and warm temperatures can\ncontribute to extreme fire behavior.",

          "description": "ESFBRO\n\nThe Brownsville Texas National Weather Service Office has\nimplemented Advanced Hydrologic Prediction Service (AHPS) for the\nLos Olmos Creek basin in Deep South Texas. AHPS enables the\nNational Weather Service to provide long-range probabilistic\noutlooks. This service is also available on the internet.\n\nIn the table below...the 90 through 10 percent columns indicate\nthe chance the creek could rise above the listed stage levels in\nthe next 90 days. Example: The Los Olmos Creek near Falfurrias\nhas a flood stage of 11 feet. There is a 50 percent chance the\nFalfurrias forecast point will rise above 2.2 feet during the\nnext 90 days.\n\nChance of Exceeding Stages at Specific Locations\nValid [09/03/2025 - 12/02/2025]\n\nLocation    FS(FT)  90%  80%  70%  60%  50%  40%  30%  20%  10%\n--------    -----   ---  ---  ---  ---  ---  ---  ---  ---  ---\nLos Olmos Creek\nFalfurrias  11.0   1.8  1.8  1.8  2.0  2.2  2.8  3.5  4.5  4.8\n\nThis long-range probabilistic outlook contains numbers that are\ncalculated using multiple scenarios from 50 years of historical\nclimatological and stream flow data. These numbers also take\ninto account current conditions of the creek and soil moisture.\nBy providing the complete range of probabilistic numbers...the\nlevel of risk associated with the long-range planning decisions\ncan be determined.\n\nAdditional supportive data and explanation are available on the\ninternet at:\nhttp://water.weather.gov/ahps2/long_range.php?wfo=bro\n\nLong range probabilistic outlooks are issued around the third\nThursday of every month.",
          "instruction": null,
          "response": "Monitor",
          "parameters": {
            "AWIPSidentifier": [
              "ESFBRO"
            ],
            "WMOidentifier": [
              "FGUS74 KBRO 032049"
            ],
            "NWSheadline": [
              "Advanced Hydrologic Prediction Service (AHPS) long range probabilistic outlook for the Los Olmos Creek basin in Deep South Texas"
            ],
            "BLOCKCHANNEL": [
              "EAS",
              "NWEM",
              "CMAS"
            ]
          },

          "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued September 3 at 1:45PM PDT by NWS Pendleton OR",
          "description": "The Washington State Department of Ecology and/or the Yakima\nRegional Clean Air Agency has issued an Air Quality Alert for\nKittitas, Yakima, Klickitat, Benton, Walla Walla, Franklin, and\nColumbia counties until further notice due to current and expected\nwildfire smoke from regional wildfires.\n\nWhen air quality is unhealthy, everyone should reduce exposure. Limit\ntime outside, avoid strenuous outdoor activity, and follow tips for\ncleaner indoor air. Hot temperatures will increase the risk of heat-\nrelated illnesses. Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-\nconditioned room, stay out of the sun, and check up on relatives and\nneighbors.\n\nInformation about air quality from the Washington Department of\nEcology Web site is available at http://www.ecy.wa.gov/air.html or\ncall 360-407-6000.Information about air quality is on the Yakima\nRegional Clean Air Agency Web site at http://www.yakimacleanair.org\nor call 509-834-2050.",

          "headline": "Flood Watch issued September 3 at 1:30PM MST until September 5 at 12:00AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ",
          "description": "* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.\n\n* WHERE...A portion of south central Arizona, including the\nfollowing areas, Aguila Valley, Apache Junction/Gold Canyon,\nBuckeye/Avondale, Cave Creek/New River, Central Phoenix, Deer\nValley, Dripping Springs, East Valley, Fountain Hills/East Mesa,\nGila Bend, Globe/Miami, Mazatzal Mountains, New River Mesa, North\nPhoenix/Glendale, Northwest Pinal County, Northwest Valley,\nPinal/Superstition Mountains, Rio Verde/Salt River, San Carlos,\nScottsdale/Paradise Valley, Sonoran Desert Natl Monument, South\nMountain/Ahwatukee, Southeast Gila County, Southeast Valley/Queen\nCreek, Superior, Tonopah Desert, Tonto Basin and West Pinal County.\n\n* WHEN...From Thursday afternoon through Thursday evening.\n\n* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers,\ncreeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.\nLow-water crossings may be flooded.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
          "instruction": "You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible Flood\nWarnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be prepared\nto take action should flooding develop.",

          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Phoenix AZ",
          "headline": "Flood Watch issued September 3 at 1:30PM MST until September 5 at 12:00AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ",
          "description": "* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.\n\n* WHERE...Portions of southwest Arizona, including the following\nareas, Central La Paz, Gila River Valley, Kofa, Parker Valley,\nSoutheast Yuma County and Yuma and California, including the\nfollowing areas, Chiriaco Summit, Chuckwalla Mountains, Chuckwalla\nValley, Imperial County Southeast, Imperial County Southwest,\nImperial County West, Imperial Valley, Palo Verde Valley and\nSalton Sea.\n\n* WHEN...From Thursday afternoon through Thursday evening.\n\n* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers,\ncreeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.\nLow-water crossings may be flooded.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
          "instruction": "You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible Flood\nWarnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be prepared\nto take action should flooding develop.",
          "response": "Prepare",

          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Fort Worth TX",
          "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued September 3 at 3:27PM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX",
          "description": "AQAFWD\n\nThe Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued\nan Ozone Action Day for the Dallas-Fort Worth area for Thursday,\nSeptember 4, 2025.\n\nAtmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing\nhigh levels of ozone air pollution in the Dallas-Fort Worth area\non Thursday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a\nride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work,\navoiding drive-through lanes, conserving energy, and keeping your\nvehicle properly tuned.\n\nFor more information on ozone:\n\nOzone: The Facts (www.tceq.texas.gov/goto/ozonefacts)\n\nAir North Texas: (www.airnorthtexas.org)\n\nEPA Air Now\n(www.airnow.gov/index.cfm?action.local_state&STATEID=45&TAB=0)\n\nTake care of Texas (www.takecareoftexas.org)\n\nNorth Central Texas Council of Governments Air Quality\n(www.nctcog.org/trans/air/index.asp)",
          "instruction": null,

          "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued September 3 at 3:19PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX",
          "description": "AQAHGX\n\nThe Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an\nOzone Action Day for the Houston, Galveston, and Brazoria area for\nThursday, September 4, 2025.\n\nAtmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing\nhigh levels of ozone pollution in the Houston, Galveston, and\nsurrounding areas on Thursday.           "headline": "Gale Watch issued September 3 at 3:48PM EDT until September 5 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Grand Rapids MI",
          "description": "* WHAT...For the Small Craft Advisory, west winds 10 to 20 knots\nwith gusts up to 25 knots and waves 3 to 6 feet. For the Gale\nWatch, southwest gales to 40 knots and waves 7 to 12 feet\npossible.\n\n* WHERE...St Joseph to Manistee.\n\n* WHEN...For the Small Craft Advisory, until 2 AM EDT Friday.\nFor the Gale Watch, from late Thursday night through Friday\nafternoon.\n\n* IMPACTS...Strong winds can cause hazardous waves which could\ncapsize or damage vessels and reduce visibility.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Winds and waves will remain elevated into\ntonight. Winds will shift to the northwest this evening behind a\ncold front. Waves will be in the 4 to 7 foot range tonight. A\nbrief lull in the wind and waves occurs on Thursday before a\nmore significant ramp up on Thursday night into Friday morning.\nA surge of wind will reach 40-45 knots resulting in waves\nbuilding towards 12 feet Friday morning. The lake will be very\nfall like with stronger winds and larger waves into the weekend.",
          "instruction": "Mariners should consider altering plans to avoid possible\nhazardous conditions.  Remain in port, seek safe harbor, alter\ncourse, and/or secure the vessel for severe wind and waves.",

          "messageType": "Alert",

          "severity": "Unknown",
          "certainty": "Unknown",
          "urgency": "Unknown",
          "event": "Air Quality Alert",
          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Omaha/Valley NE",
          "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued September 3 at 2:46PM CDT by NWS Omaha/Valley NE",
          "description": "The following is transmitted in collaboration with the Nebraska\nDepartment of Health and Human Services and the Nebraska\nDepartment of Environment and Energy...\n\nWHAT...Air Quality Alert\n\nWHERE...Eastern Nebraska\n\nWHEN... 09/03/2025 6:00 PM until 09/04/2025 11:00 AM\n\nPOLLUTANT...PM 2.5 particulates\n\nAIR QUALITY INDEX...Moderate to Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups\n\nADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n\nAn alert for possible Moderate (Air Quality Index yellow category)\nto Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups AQI (Air Quality Index orange\ncategory) due to smoke has been issued for the following Nebraska\ncounties: Antelope, Boone, Burt, Butler, Cass, Cedar, Clay,\nColfax, Cuming,  Dakota, Dixon, Dodge, Douglas, Fillmore, Gage,\nHamilton, Jefferson, Johnson, Knox, Lancaster, Madison, Merrick,\nNance, Nemaha, Nuckolls, Otoe, Pawnee, Pierce, Platte, Polk,\nRichardson, Saline, Sarpy, Saunders, Seward, Stanton, Thayer,\nThurston, Washington, Wayne, and York, from September 03, 6:00 pm\nthrough September 04, 11:00 am.\n\nDuring Moderate AQI (yellow category) conditions, those who are\nunusually sensitive to particle pollution may experience health\neffects. When conditions rise to the yellow category, those who\nare unusually sensitive are advised to consider shortening outdoor\nactivities and reducing the intensity of these activities.\nSymptoms such as coughing or shortness of breath are signs to take\nit easier.\n\nDuring Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups (orange category)\nconditions, members of sensitive groups may experience health\neffects. Sensitive groups include people with heart or lung\ndisease, older adults, and children. When conditions rise to the\norange category, sensitive groups are advised to reduce prolonged\nor heavy exertion and avoid intense outdoor activities.\n\nSmoke from Canadian wildfires may affect the air quality in\nNebraska.  Smoke levels and wind directions are monitored by\nNebraska and other states to predict when impacts to the air\nquality may occur.\n\nInformation regarding wildfires and Impacts in Nebraska is\navailable from the Nebraska Department of Water, Energy, and\nEnvironment (DWEE) at https://dee.nebraska.gov/wildfires-and-\nimpacts-nebraska.\n\nAlerts are based on data available from weather forecasts, smoke\nplume modeling, satellite imagery, and from air quality monitors\nlocated in Omaha, Bellevue, Blair, Lincoln, Beatrice, Grand\nIsland, and Scottsbluff.\n\nAdvisories for smoke and air quality are issued for affected areas\nby the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) and\nDepartment of Water, Energy, and Environment (DWEE) and posted on\nagency webpages and social media sites.  By notifying the media\nand local health departments, alerts help citizens protect their\nhealth by informing them of days where outdoor activities should\nbe reduced or avoided to minimize exposure to smoke.",
          "instruction": null,
          "response": "Monitor",
          "parameters": {
            "AWIPSidentifier": [
              "AQAOAX"
            ],

          "description": "* WHAT...High wave action, strong currents, and dangerous\nswimming conditions expected.           "urgency": "Unknown",
          "event": "Air Quality Alert",
          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Hastings NE",
          "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued September 3 at 2:44PM CDT by NWS Hastings NE",
          "description": "The following is transmitted in collaboration with the Nebraska\nDepartment of Health and Human Services and the Nebraska\nDepartment of Environment and Energy...\n\nWHAT...Air Quality Alert\n\nWHERE...Eastern Nebraska\n\nWHEN... 09/03/2025 6:00 PM until 09/04/2025 11:00 AM\n\nPOLLUTANT...PM 2.5 particulates\n\nAIR QUALITY INDEX...Moderate to Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups\n\nADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n\nAn alert for possible Moderate (Air Quality Index yellow category)\nto Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups AQI (Air Quality Index orange\ncategory) due to smoke has been issued for the following Nebraska\ncounties: Antelope, Boone, Burt, Butler, Cass, Cedar, Clay,\nColfax, Cuming,  Dakota, Dixon, Dodge, Douglas, Fillmore, Gage,\nHamilton, Jefferson, Johnson, Knox, Lancaster, Madison, Merrick,\nNance, Nemaha, Nuckolls, Otoe, Pawnee, Pierce, Platte, Polk,\nRichardson, Saline, Sarpy, Saunders, Seward, Stanton, Thayer,\nThurston, Washington, Wayne, and York, from September 03, 6:00 pm\nthrough September 04, 11:00 am.\n\nDuring Moderate AQI (yellow category) conditions, those who are\nunusually sensitive to particle pollution may experience health\neffects. When conditions rise to the yellow category, those who\nare unusually sensitive are advised to consider shortening outdoor\nactivities and reducing the intensity of these activities.\nSymptoms such as coughing or shortness of breath are signs to take\nit easier.\n\nDuring Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups (orange category)\nconditions, members of sensitive groups may experience health\neffects. Sensitive groups include people with heart or lung\ndisease, older adults, and children. When conditions rise to the\norange category, sensitive groups are advised to reduce prolonged\nor heavy exertion and avoid intense outdoor activities.\n\nSmoke from Canadian wildfires may affect the air quality in\nNebraska.  Smoke levels and wind directions are monitored by\nNebraska and other states to predict when impacts to the air\nquality may occur.\n\nInformation regarding wildfires and Impacts in Nebraska is\navailable from the Nebraska Department of Water, Energy, and\nEnvironment (DWEE) at https://dee.nebraska.gov/wildfires-and-\nimpacts-nebraska.\n\nAlerts are based on data available from weather forecasts, smoke\nplume modeling, satellite imagery, and from air quality monitors\nlocated in Omaha, Bellevue, Blair, Lincoln, Beatrice, Grand\nIsland, and Scottsbluff.\n\nAdvisories for smoke and air quality are issued for affected areas\nby the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) and\nDepartment of Water, Energy, and Environment (DWEE) and posted on\nagency webpages and social media sites.  By notifying the media\nand local health departments, alerts help citizens protect their\nhealth by informing them of days where outdoor activities should\nbe reduced or avoided to minimize exposure to smoke.",
          "instruction": null,
          "response": "Monitor",
          "parameters": {

              "AQAGID"
            ],

              "CMAS"
            ]

          "senderName": "NWS Fairbanks AK",
          "headline": "Flood Advisory issued September 3 at 11:44AM AKDT until September 4 at 4:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK",
          "description": "* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.\n\n* WHERE...Kobuk River at Kobuk.\n\n* WHEN...Until 400 PM AKDT Thursday.\n\n* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poorly drained areas.\nThe old road is flooded and water levels are near the new road.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- As of Wednesday morning, the public has reported minor\nflooding in Kobuk.           "instruction": "Stay tuned to further developments by listening to your local radio,\ntelevision, or NOAA Weather Radio for further information.",

          "senderName": "NWS Pendleton OR",
          "headline": "Heat Advisory issued September 3 at 12:30PM PDT until September 4 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Pendleton OR",
          "description": "* WHAT...Hot conditions with afternoon high temperatures of 85 to 95\ndegrees. This will pose a moderate to major risk of heat-related\nillness.\n\n* WHERE...In Oregon, Northern Blue Mountains of Oregon. In\nWashington, Northwest Blue Mountains.\n\n* WHEN...Until 8 PM PDT Thursday.\n\n* IMPACTS...Hot temperatures may cause heat illnesses.",
          "instruction": "Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out of\nthe sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young children and\npets should never be left unattended in vehicles under any\ncircumstances.\n\nTake extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When\npossible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or\nevening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat\nstroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when possible.\nTo reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational Safety and\nHealth Administration recommends scheduling frequent rest breaks in\nshaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone overcome by heat\nshould be moved to a cool and shaded location. Heat stroke is an\nemergency! Call 9 1 1.\n\nFor sheltering information and other human services in your area,\ndial 2 1 1 during business hours or visit 211info.org for Oregon or\nwa211.org for Washington anytime.",

          "senderName": "NWS Albany NY",
          "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued September 3 at 3:17PM EDT by NWS Albany NY",
          "description": "Fine fuels remain very dry across the area according to the\nVermont Department of Forests, Parks and Recreation. Southerly\nwinds will quickly increase to 10 to 15 mph with gusts up to 25\nmph across southern Vermont. This, combined with expected low\nrelative humidity values between 35 and 40 percent will create\nnear critical fire weather conditions Thursday. Winds will be\nstrongest between noon and 8 PM, coinciding with the timing of the\nminimum relative humidity values. If any fires were to start the\nweather and fuel conditions could cause fires to quickly get out\nof control and be difficult to contain. Fire weather conditions\nareawide will quickly improve as confidence increases in wetting\nrainfall Thursday night.\n\nFor more information about the current fire danger rating, any burn\nrestrictions, and wildfire prevention and education, please visit\nyour state forestry or environmental protection website.",

          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Albany NY",
          "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued September 3 at 3:13PM EDT by NWS Albany NY",
          "description": "The combination of recent dry weather and increasing drought,\nsoutherly winds gusting between 25 and 35 mph and relative\nhumidity values between 35 and 40 percent will contribute to an\nelevated risk for fire spread tomorrow. The risk will be greatest\nacross portions of the Hudson Valley Fire Danger Rating Area which\nincludes the following counties: Warren, Saratoga, Washington,\nSchenectady, Albany, Rensselaer, Columbia, Dutchess, eastern\nGreene and eastern Ulster counties.\n\nAny fires that develop in these areas could spread rapidly.\nResidents are encouraged to exercise caution if handling any\npotential ignition sources, such as machinery, cigarettes, or\nmatches.\n\nFor more information about wildfire danger and wildfire\nprevention, please visit the New York Department of Environmental\nConservation website at http://dec.ny.gov/environmental-\nprotection/wildfires.",
          "instruction": null,
          "response": "Execute",

          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Burlington VT",
          "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued September 3 at 3:07PM EDT by NWS Burlington VT",
          "description": "Fine fuels remain very dry across the area, particularly across\nthe Connecticut and Champlain Valleys, according to the Vermont\nDepartment of Forests, Parks and Recreation and the New York State\nDepartment of Environmental Conservation. Portions of central and\nnorthern Vermont and parts of northern New York also remain in\nmoderate drought. Southerly winds will quickly increase to 10 to\n15 MPH with gusts up to 25 MPH possible across Vermont. Localized\ngusts up to 35 MPH are possible particularly in the north to\nsouth oriented valleys of the Champlain Valley and portions of\nnorthern New York. This, combined with expected low relative\nhumidity values between 25% to 35% will create near critical fire\nweather conditions Thursday. Winds will be strongest between noon\nand 8 PM, coinciding with the timing of the minimum relative\nhumidity values. If any fires were to start the weather and fuel\nconditions could cause fires to quickly get out of control and be\ndifficult to contain. Fire weather conditions areawide will\nquickly improve as confidence increases in wetting rainfall\nThursday night.\n\n\nFor more information about the current fire danger rating, any burn\nrestrictions, and wildfire prevention and education, please visit\nyour state forestry or environmental protection website.",
          "instruction": null,
          "response": "Execute",

          "description": "* WHAT...For the Small Craft Advisory, Highest gusts up to 30\nkts from the west and highest waves around 6 feet.           "instruction": "Mariners should consider altering plans to avoid possible\nhazardous conditions.  Remain in port, seek safe harbor, alter\ncourse, and/or secure the vessel for severe wind and highest\nwaves.",

          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Duluth MN",
          "headline": "Frost Advisory issued September 3 at 1:55PM CDT until September 4 at 8:00AM CDT by NWS Duluth MN",
          "description": "* WHAT...Temperatures as low as 32 will result in frost formation.\n\n* WHERE...Northern Aitkin, Koochiching, North Cass, Itasca, Central\nand North St. Louis Counties. This includes the Tribal Lands of\nthe Mille Lacs Band, Big Sandy Lake area and the Bois Forte Band,\nNett Lake, Lake Vermilion and, Deer Creek areas. Other locations\nincluding Voyageurs National Park. This also includes the Boundary\nWaters western area.\n\n* WHEN...From 2 AM to 8 AM CDT Thursday.\n\n* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation. Sensitive\noutdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.",
          "instruction": "Take steps now to protect tender plants from the cold.",
          "response": "Prepare",
          "parameters": {

            ],

          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Jacksonville FL",
          "headline": "Rip Current Statement issued September 3 at 2:51PM EDT until September 4 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL",
          "description": "* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, minor coastal flooding\naround times of high tide. For the High Rip Current Risk,\ndangerous rip currents.\n\n* WHERE...Coastal Flagler, Northeast Coastal St. Johns and\nSoutheast Coastal St. Johns Counties.\n\n* WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 6 AM EDT Friday.\nFor the High Rip Current Risk, through late tonight.\n\n* IMPACTS...Flooding of lots, parks, and roads with only\nisolated road closures expected. Rip currents can sweep even\nthe best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.",
          "instruction": "If travel is required, allow extra time as some roads may be\nclosed. Do not drive around barricades or through water of\nunknown depth. Take the necessary actions to protect flood-prone\nproperty.\n\nSwim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and\nfloat. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a\ndirection following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the\nshore and call or wave for help.",
          "response": "Avoid",
          "parameters": {

              "CFWJAX"
            ],

          "headline": "Coastal Flood Advisory issued September 3 at 2:51PM EDT until September 5 at 6:00AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL",
          "description": "* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, minor coastal flooding\naround times of high tide. For the High Rip Current Risk,\ndangerous rip currents.\n\n* WHERE...Coastal Flagler, Northeast Coastal St. Johns and\nSoutheast Coastal St. Johns Counties.\n\n* WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 6 AM EDT Friday.\nFor the High Rip Current Risk, through late tonight.\n\n* IMPACTS...Flooding of lots, parks, and roads with only\nisolated road closures expected. Rip currents can sweep even\nthe best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.",
          "instruction": "If travel is required, allow extra time as some roads may be\nclosed. Do not drive around barricades or through water of\nunknown depth. Take the necessary actions to protect flood-prone\nproperty.\n\nSwim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and\nfloat. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a\ndirection following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the\nshore and call or wave for help.",

          "headline": "Beach Hazards Statement issued September 3 at 2:50PM EDT until September 4 at 5:00PM EDT by NWS Northern Indiana",
          "description": "* WHAT...High wave action, strong currents, and dangerous swimming\nconditions expected. Piers will be heavily swamped by waves.\nWaves build to 3 to 6 feet this evening and persist into\nThursday afternoon.\n\n* WHERE...In Indiana, Northern La Porte county. In Michigan,\nNorthern Berrien and Southern Berrien counties.\n\n* WHEN...From 8 PM EDT /7 PM CDT/ this evening through Thursday\nafternoon.\n\n* IMPACTS...Strong currents can pull swimmers into deeper water\nand high waves can sweep people off piers.",
          "instruction": "Remain out of the water to avoid hazardous swimming conditions.\nDo not venture out on piers.",

          "event": "Flood Warning",
          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Twin Cities/Chanhassen MN",
          "headline": "Flood Warning issued September 3 at 1:42PM CDT by NWS Twin Cities/Chanhassen MN",
          "description": "...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in\nMinnesota...\n\nMinnesota River at Morton affecting Renville and Redwood Counties.\n\nMinnesota River at Montevideo affecting Lac qui Parle, Chippewa\nand Yellow Medicine Counties.\n\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\n\n* WHERE...Minnesota River at Montevideo.\n\n* WHEN...Until further notice.\n\n* IMPACTS...At 14.0 feet, Low lying areas and some roads along the\nriver begin flooding, along with some basements of houses along\nthe river.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 100 PM CDT Wednesday, the stage was 15.0 feet.\n- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours\nending at 100 PM CDT Wednesday was 15.1 feet.\n- Forecast...The river will slowly fall to near 14 feet by the\nmiddle of next week.\n- Flood stage is 14.0 feet.",
          "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nCaution is urged when walking near riverbanks.",
          "response": "Avoid",
          "parameters": {

          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Twin Cities/Chanhassen MN",
          "headline": "Flood Warning issued September 3 at 1:42PM CDT until September 6 at 1:00AM CDT by NWS Twin Cities/Chanhassen MN",
          "description": "...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in\nMinnesota...\n\nMinnesota River at Morton affecting Renville and Redwood Counties.\n\nMinnesota River at Montevideo affecting Lac qui Parle, Chippewa\nand Yellow Medicine Counties.\n\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\n\n* WHERE...Minnesota River at Morton.\n\n* WHEN...Until late Friday night.\n\n* IMPACTS...At 23.0 feet, Riverside Rd and Front Street flooded in\nNorth Redwood.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 100 PM CDT Wednesday, the stage was 21.4 feet.\n- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours\nending at 100 PM CDT Wednesday was 21.5 feet.\n- Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage\nFriday morning and continue falling to 19.7 feet Wednesday,\nSeptember 10.\n- Flood stage is 21.0 feet.",
          "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nCaution is urged when walking near riverbanks.",
          "response": "Avoid",

          "senderName": "NWS Juneau AK",
          "headline": "Heat Advisory issued September 3 at 10:17AM AKDT until September 3 at 7:00PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK",
          "description": "* WHAT...Temperatures up to 80.\n\n* WHERE...Haines Borough and Klukwan and City and Borough of\nJuneau.\n\n* WHEN...Until 7 PM AKDT this evening.\n\n* IMPACTS...Individuals not accustomed to these unusually hot\ntemperatures for this region may experience heat related\nillnesses.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Wednesday's warmest temperatures are\nexpected along Haines Highway. Anticipating the warmest\ntemperatures inland, away from water, during the afternoon.",
          "instruction": "Drink plenty of fluids and check up on elderly and vulnerable\nrelatives and neighbors.\n\nYoung children and pets should never be left unattended in\nvehicles under any circumstances as vehicle interiors can reach\nextreme temperatures in as little as 10 minutes\n\nTake extra precautions when working in the sun. Wear sunscreen\nand lightweight, loose fitting clothing. Try to limit strenuous\nactivities to early morning or evening. Take action when you see\nsymptoms of heat exhaustion and heat stroke\n\nClose curtains during the daytime to reduce sun insulation into\nthe home and open windows at night to allow the home to cool off.\nUtilize fans or community buildings with air conditioning.",
          "response": "Execute",

          "description": "* WHAT...Dangerous swimming currents are expected due to high\nwaves of 3 to 5 feet and rip currents.\n\n* WHERE...Emmet, Benzie and Manistee Counties, and Beaver Island\nand surrounding islands.\n\n* WHEN...Until midnight EDT tonight.\n\n* IMPACTS...Strong currents can pull swimmers into deeper water\nand high waves can sweep people off piers.",

          "headline": "Coastal Flood Advisory issued September 3 at 2:07PM EDT until September 4 at 7:00AM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC",
          "description": "* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, up to one half foot of\ninundation above ground level expected in low lying areas due\nto tidal flooding. Flooding of much of the City Dock parking lot is\noccurring.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Tides one to one and a half feet above\nnormal. The next high tide at Annapolis U.S. Naval Academy is at\n3:29 AM and 3:00 PM.",
          "instruction": "If travel is required, allow extra time as some roads may be\nclosed. Do not drive around barricades or through water of\nunknown depth. Take the necessary actions to protect flood-prone\nproperty.",
          "response": "Monitor",

            ],

          "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued September 3 at 10:28AM PDT by NWS Spokane WA",
          "description": "An Air Quality Alert has been issued by the following agencies:\n\nWashington Department of Ecology\nSpokane Regional Clean Air Agency\n\nAn Air Quality Alert has been issued for Stevens, Spokane, Lincoln,\nGrant, Pend Oreille, Ferry, Chelan, Douglas, Adams, Garfield,\nOkanogan, Whitman, and Asotin Counties until further notice due to\ncurrent wildfire smoke from regional wildfires. When air quality is\nUnhealthy, everyone should reduce exposure. Limit time outside,\navoid strenuous outdoor activity, and follow tips for cleaner indoor\nair. Hot temperatures will increase the risk of heat- related\nillnesses. Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room,\nstay out of the sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors.",

          "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued September 3 at 11:05AM MDT by NWS Billings MT",
          "description": "The following message is transmitted on behalf of the Wyoming\nDepartment of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division and the\nWyoming Department of Health.\n\nWHAT...Air Quality Alert for Wildfire Smoke.\n\nWHERE...Sheridan County, Wyoming.\n\nWHEN...11 AM MDT Wednesday through 11 AM MDT Thursday.\n\nIMPACTS...Heavy smoke from Western Canadian wildfires continues to\nbe observed across much of northeastern Wyoming.\n\nHEALTH INFORMATION...The Wyoming Department of Health recommends the\nelderly, young children, and individuals with respiratory problems\navoid excessive physical exertion and minimize outdoor activities\nduring this time. Wildfire smoke is made up of a variety of\npollutants, including particulate matter and ozone, which can cause\nrespiratory health effects. Although these people are most\nsusceptible to health impacts, the Department of Health also advises\nthat everyone should avoid prolonged exposure to poor air quality\nconditions.\n\nCURRENT CONDITIONS...The Wyoming Department of Environmental\nQuality, Air Quality Division offers near real-time air quality data\nfor Wyoming's monitoring stations and health effects information to\nhelp the public interpret current conditions. Current air quality\nconditions across the state of Wyoming can be found at\nhttp://www.wyvisnet.com/",
          "instruction": null,
          "response": "Monitor",

          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Tucson AZ",
          "headline": "Flood Watch issued September 3 at 10:05AM MST until September 6 at 5:00PM MST by NWS Tucson AZ",
          "description": "* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.\n\n* WHERE...A portion of Southeast Arizona, including the following\nareas, Catalina and Rincon Mountains, Chiricahua Mountains,\nDragoon and Mule and Huachuca and Santa Rita Mountains, Eastern\nCochise County below 5000 feet, Galiuro and Pinaleno Mountains,\nSoutheast Pinal County, Tucson Metro Area, Upper Gila River\nValley, Upper San Pedro River Valley, Upper Santa Cruz River\nValley/Altar Valley and White Mountains of Graham and Greenlee\nCounties.\n\n* WHEN...From Friday afternoon through Saturday afternoon.\n\n* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers,\ncreeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.\nFlooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Low-water\ncrossings may be flooded.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- Moisture associated with Hurricane Lorena may bring periods\nof heavy rain to portions of southeast Arizona. Rainfall\namounts of 1 to 2 inches with up to 4 inches in the mountains\nare possible.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
          "instruction": "You should monitor later forecasts and be prepared to take action\nshould Flash Flood Warnings be issued.",

          "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued September 3 at 10:52AM MDT by NWS Riverton WY",
          "description": "The following message is transmitted on behalf of the Wyoming\nDepartment of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division, and the\nWyoming Department of Health.\n\n* WHAT...Air Quality Alert for Wildfire Smoke.\n\n* WHERE...Northeast Wyoming, including the eastern foothills of the\nBighorn Mountains and lower elevations of Johnson County.\n\n* WHEN...Until 11 AM Thursday, September 4.\n\n* IMPACTS...Smoke from Western Canadian wildfires continues to be\nobserved across much of northeastern Wyoming. The smoke is limiting\nvisibilities at times.\n\nHEALTH INFORMATION...The Wyoming Department of Health recommends\nthat the elderly, young children, and individuals with respiratory\nproblems avoid excessive physical exertion and minimize outdoor\nactivities during this time. Wildfire smoke is made up of a variety\nof pollutants, including particulate matter and ozone, which can\ncause respiratory health effects. Although these people are most\nsusceptible to health impacts, the Department of Health also advises\nthat everyone should avoid prolonged exposure to poor air quality\nconditions.\n\nCURRENT CONDITIONS...The Wyoming Department of Environmental\nQuality, Air Quality Division offers near real-time air quality data\nfor Wyoming's monitoring stations and health effects information to\nhelp the public interpret current conditions. Current air quality\nconditions across the state of Wyoming can be found at\nhttp://www.wyvisnet.com/.",

          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Phoenix AZ",
          "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued September 3 at 9:51AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ",
          "description": "AQAPSR\n\nThe Arizona Department of Environmental Quality (ADEQ) has issued an\nOzone High Pollution Advisory for the Phoenix Metro Area Through Thursday.\n\nThis means that forecast weather conditions combined with existing\nozone levels are expected to result in local maximum 8-hour ozone\nconcentrations that pose a health risk. Adverse health effects\nincrease as air quality deteriorates.\n\nOzone is an air contaminant which can cause breathing difficulties\nfor children, older adults, as well as persons with respiratory\nproblems. A decrease in physical activity is recommended.\n\nYou are urged to car pool, telecommute or use mass transit.\nThe use of gasoline-powered equipment should be reduced or done late\nin the day.\n\nFor details on this High Pollution Advisory, visit the ADEQ internet\nsite at www.azdeq.gov/forecast/phoenix or call 602-771-2300.",
          "instruction": null,

          "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued September 3 at 10:44AM MDT by NWS Rapid City SD",
          "description": "The following message is transmitted in collaboration with the\nWyoming Department of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division,\nand the Wyoming Department of Health.\n\n* WHAT...Air Quality Alert for Wildfire Smoke.\n\n* WHERE...Northeast Wyoming.\n\n* WHEN...11 AM MDT Wednesday through 11 AM MDT Thursday.\n\n* IMPACTS...Poor air quality due to wildfire smoke.",
          "instruction": "The Wyoming Department of Health recommends the elderly, young\nchildren, and individuals with respiratory problems avoid excessive\nphysical exertion and minimize outdoor activities during this time.\nWildfire smoke is made up of a variety of pollutants, including\nparticulate matter and ozone, which can cause respiratory health\neffect. Although these people are most susceptible to health\nimpacts, the Department of Health also advises that everyone should\navoid prolonged exposure to poor air quality conditions.",
          "response": "Monitor",

Isolated higher gusts along Highway 35 on the east side\nof Flathead Lake and the Swan Range, as well as Highway 93 on the\nwestern slopes of the Whitefish Range.\n\n* WHERE...Flathead/Mission Valleys and West Glacier Region.\n\n* WHEN...From 6 AM Thursday to midnight MDT Thursday Night.\n\n* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will blow around unsecured objects.           "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Fairbanks AK",
          "headline": "Flood Watch issued September 3 at 7:35AM AKDT until September 4 at 4:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK",
          "description": "* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be\npossible.\n\n* WHERE...Including the Noatak, Kobuk, and Koyukuk Rivers.\n\n* WHEN...Through Thursday afternoon.\n\n* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff from last week's rainfall is resulting\nin flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and\nflood-prone locations.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- Additional rainfall of up to an inch expected through\nThursday for most of the area which may slow down the\nrecession of elevated water levels.\n\n- Http://www.weather.gov/aprfc",
          "instruction": "Persons living along streams should stay alert and be prepared to\ntake action if a warning or advisory is issued, or flooding is\nobserved.\n\nYou should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible Flood\nWarnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be prepared\nto take action should flooding develop.\n\nStay tuned to further developments by listening to your local radio,\ntelevision, or NOAA Weather Radio for further information.",

          "event": "Beach Hazards Statement",
          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Newport/Morehead City NC",
          "headline": "Beach Hazards Statement issued September 3 at 11:21AM EDT until September 3 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC",
          "description": "* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.\n\n* WHERE...The beaches north of Cape Hatteras.\n\n* WHEN...From 8 AM EDT this morning through this evening.\n\n* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away\nfrom shore into deeper water.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip\ncurrents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,\nwhich will occur around 10 AM this morning.",
          "instruction": "Life-threatening rip currents. If caught in a rip current, remain\ncalm. Swim in a direction following the shoreline. If tired,\nfloat or tread water until out of the rip current. If unable to\nescape, face the shore and call or wave for help.",
          "response": "Avoid",
          "parameters": {
            "AWIPSidentifier": [
              "CFWMHX"
            ],
            "WMOidentifier": [
              "WHUS42 KMHX 031521"
            ],

          "event": "Red Flag Warning",
          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Medford OR",
          "headline": "Red Flag Warning issued September 3 at 8:07AM PDT until September 3 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR",
          "description": "* AFFECTED AREA...In California, Fire weather zone 285. In\nOregon, Fire weather zones 617, 623, 624 and 625.\n\n* THUNDERSTORMS...Scattered thunderstorms with abundant\nlightningpossible. Storms may produce little or no rain, and\nlightning strikes outside of precipitation cores are\npossible, and may cause many new fire starts. Thunderstorms\nare expected to continue overnight and through Wednesday\nafternoon along and east of the Cascades.\n\n* OUTFLOW WINDS...Gusts of 35 to 50 mph could travel outward up\nto 25 miles from thunderstorm cores.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...In addition to thunderstorm potential,\nconditions on Tuesday will be hot, dry, breezy, and unstable,\nadding to the heightened fire weather concerns for the day.\n\n* DETAILED URL...View the hazard area in detail at\nhttps://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr",
          "instruction": "Follow all fire restrictions. You can find your county's\nemergency sign up form as well as links to fire restrictions at\nweather.gov/medford/wildfire. One less spark, one less wildfire.\n\nBe sure you're signed up for your county's emergency alert\nsystem. Familiarize yourself with your emergency plan and make\nsure you listen to emergency services. Visit ready.gov/plan for\nmore information.\n\nA Red Flag Warning is issued when we identify weather conditions\nthat promote rapid spread of fire which may become life-\nthreatening. This does not mean there is a fire. These conditions\nare either occurring now or will begin soon. It is important to\nhave multiple ways to receive information from authorities.",
          "response": "Prepare",
          "parameters": {
            "AWIPSidentifier": [
              "RFWMFR"
            ],
            "WMOidentifier": [
              "WWUS86 KMFR 031507"
            ],
            "NWSheadline": [
              "RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM PDT THIS EVENING FOR ABUNDANT LIGHTNING ON DRY FUELS FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 285, 617, 623, 624, AND 625"
            ],
            "BLOCKCHANNEL": [

            ],

          "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued September 3 at 8:55AM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT",
          "description": "AQAMT\n\nThe Montana Department of Environmental Quality has issued an air\nquality alert for Flathead, Lake, Lincoln, Mineral, Missoula, Powell,\nSanders, Glacier counties in effect until 9AM on 09/04/2025\nAn Air Quality Alert means that particulates have been trending\nupwards and that an exceedence of the 24 hour National Ambient Air\nQuality Standard (NAAQS) has occurred or may occur in the near\nfuture.\n\nElevated particulate levels from wildfire smoke\n\nAs of 8AM on 09/03/2025, particulate levels in Great Falls are\nUnhealthy for Sensitive Groups.\n\nAs of 8AM on 09/03/2025, particulate levels in Billings, Butte,\nColumbia Falls, Cut Bank, Glendive, Hamilton, Havre, Lewistown,\nSeeley Lake, Sidney and Thompson Falls are Moderate.\n\nWhen air quality is Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups... State and local\nhealth officials recommend that people with respiratory or heart\ndisease, the elderly and children should limit prolonged exertion.\n\nWhen air quality is Moderate... State and local health officials\nrecommend that unusually sensitive people should consider reducing\nprolonged or heavy exertion.\n\nFor more information visit the Montana Department of Environmental\nQuality at http://todaysair.mtdeq.us",
          "instruction": null,

          "event": "Coastal Flood Statement",
          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Honolulu HI",
          "headline": "Coastal Flood Statement issued September 3 at 3:03AM HST until September 7 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI",
          "description": "...MINOR COASTAL FLOODING DURING THE HIGH TIDE THROUGH SUNDAY\nAFTERNOON FOR LOW LYING COASTAL AREAS OF ALL ISLANDS...\n\nPeak high tides associated with the lunar cycle will lead to\nminor coastal flooding along shorelines and low lying coastal\nareas during the daily afternoon high tide through Sunday.\n\n* WHAT...Isolated minor coastal flooding expected.\n\n* WHERE...Vulnerable low-lying coastal roadways, docks, boat\nramps, and other coastal infrastructure.\n\n* WHEN...Through the afternoon hours Wednesday through Sunday at\nand around the daily peak tides.\n\n* IMPACTS...Flooding of beaches that are normally dry, minor\ncoastal erosion, and saltwater inundation.",
          "instruction": "Avoid driving through flooded roadways. If you are forced to\ndrive through salt water, be sure to rinse your vehicle with\nfresh water. Move electronics, vehicles or other valuables to\nhigher ground. Monitor vessels to ensure mooring lines don't get\ntoo tight and watch out for overwash around boat ramps. Secure\ncanoes or other watercraft stowed on beaches.",

          "event": "Flood Advisory",
          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Anchorage AK",
          "headline": "Flood Advisory issued September 3 at 4:59AM AKDT until September 4 at 9:15AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK",
          "description": "* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.\n\n* WHERE...Northern Susitna Valley in the Petersville area\n\n* WHEN...Until 915 AM AKDT Thursday.\n\n* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.\nRises in small streams. Some low-water crossings may become\nimpassable. River or stream flows are elevated.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 455 AM AKDT, another round of rain is moving up the Cook\nInlet and will move into the Susitna Valley later today.\nHeavy rain is not anticipated, but even minor amounts could\nexacerbate ongoing flooding issues along the headwaters of\nPeters Creek and Cache Creek.\n- Area creeks and streams are already running higher than\nnormal after the rainfall from last week. While waters have\nbeen receding, additional rainfall may result in rises again\nthis week.\n- Streams that may be affected include Peters Creek, Cache\nCreek, Moose Creek, Kroto Creek, and other nearby streams and\ntheir tributaries.\nLarger rivers such as that Yentna and Susitna are NOT\nexpected to rise into flood stage again.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
          "instruction": "Stay tuned to further developments by listening to your local radio,\ntelevision, or NOAA Weather Radio for further information.\n\nTurn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nFlooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where\nyou are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become\nkillers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or\ncreeks.",
          "response": "Avoid",

          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Melbourne FL",
          "headline": "Flood Warning issued September 3 at 8:58AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL",
          "description": "...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...\n\nSt Johns River Near Astor affecting Volusia and Lake Counties.\n\n.On the Saint Johns River at Astor, northerly winds and recent\nrainfall over the basin are maintaining a slow climb within Minor\nFlood Stage. The river is forecast to crest around 2.8 ft later\ntoday, then begin a slow decline through late week and this weekend.\nHowever, additional rainfall or lingering northerly winds could slow\nthe rate of decline.\n\nFor the St. Johns River...including Astor...Minor flooding is\nforecast.\n\nAdditional information is available at www.weather.gov.\n\nThe next statement will be issued late tonight at midnight EDT.\n\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\n\n* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.\n\n* WHEN...Until further notice.\n\n* IMPACTS...At 2.8 feet, Docks and boat ramps covered at South Moon\nFish Camp and approaching sea wall at Blair's Jungle Den. Water\napproaching sites closest to the river at Fish Tales RV Resort and\nAstor Landing Campground. Portion of Clair Street covered by river\nwater south of the Butler Boat Ramp. Docks underwater at the Astor\nBridge Marina and along Riveredge Drive. Portions of Fox Road are\ncovered with water nearest to the river. Acorn, Hazelnut and\nRedbud roads are underwater with yards inundated.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 8:30 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 2.7 feet.\n- Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet.\n- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours\nending at 8:30 AM EDT Wednesday was 2.7 feet.\n- Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 2.8\nfeet this afternoon.\n- Flood stage is 2.3 feet.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
          "instruction": null,
          "response": "Avoid",

          "headline": "Flood Warning issued September 3 at 7:36AM CDT by NWS Aberdeen SD",
          "description": "...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South\nDakota...\n\nJames River near Stratford affecting Spink and Brown Counties.\n\nJames River At Columbia affecting Brown County.\n\n.For sites with a river forecast, the forecast includes\nprecipitation through the next 24 hours. Any future precipitation\ncould affect the forecasts.\n\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\n\n* WHERE...James River near Stratford.\n\n* WHEN...Until further notice.\n\n* IMPACTS...At 14.0 feet, Significant amounts of agricultural lands\nbegin flooding.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 6:45 AM CDT Wednesday the stage was 14.8 feet.\n- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours\nending at 6:45 AM CDT Wednesday was 14.8 feet.\n- Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 14.9\nfeet early Friday morning.\n- Flood stage is 14.0 feet.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
          "instruction": "Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive\ncars through flooded areas.\n\nTurn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nCaution is urged when walking near riverbanks.\n\nAdditional information is available at www.weather.gov/abr.\n\nThe next statement will be issued by Saturday afternoon at 345 PM\nCDT.",

          "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued September 3 at 3:25AM PDT by NWS Portland OR",
          "description": "The Lane Regional Air Protection Agency has continued an Air Quality\nAdvisory, which is IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM PDT THURSDAY.\n\nAn Air Quality Advisory for Smoke remains in effect. Wildfires\nburning in the region combined with forecasted conditions will cause\nair quality to reach unhealthy levels at times through Thursday\nevening.\n\nPollutants in smoke can cause burning eyes, runny nose, aggravate\nheart and lung diseases, and aggravate other serious health\nproblems. Limit outdoor activities and keep children indoors if it\nis smoky.           "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Portland OR",
          "headline": "Red Flag Warning issued September 3 at 3:20AM PDT until September 3 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR",
          "description": "* AFFECTED AREA...In Oregon, Fire Weather Zone 689 Northern\nWillamette National Forest and Fire Weather Zone 690 Southern\nWillamette National Forest.\n\n* THUNDERSTORMS...A 15 to 25% chance of dry thunderstorms. Storms\nmay produce very little rainfall, increasing the risk fo new\nfire starts from dry lightning.\n\n* OUTFLOW WINDS...Instantaneous gusts as high as 40 mph. Gusts at\nthese speeds can be observed tens of miles away from the core of\nthe thunderstorm.\n\n* DRY AND UNSTABLE...Unstable conditions with elevated mixing\nheights may promote pyroconvective activity over ongoing fires.\n\n* IMPACTS...Conditions will be favorable for rapid fire spread\nwhich may threaten life and property. Thunderstorm outflow\nwinds may result in unanticipated erratic fire spread. High\ninstability may result in fire growth. Frequent lightning and\ncritically dry fuels may result in new fire starts.",
          "instruction": "A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions\nare either occurring now, or will shortly. A combination of the\nabove conditions can contribute to extreme fire behavior.",
          "response": "Prepare",
          "parameters": {

              "RFWPQR"
            ],
            "WMOidentifier": [
              "WWUS86 KPQR 031020"
            ],

          "event": "Red Flag Warning",
          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Portland OR",
          "headline": "Red Flag Warning issued September 3 at 3:20AM PDT until September 3 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR",
          "description": "* AFFECTED AREA...In Oregon, Fire Weather Zone 688 Mt. Hood\nNational Forest Region.\n\n* THUNDERSTORMS...A 15 to 20% chance of dry thunderstorms. Storms\nmay produce very little rainfall, increasing the risk of new\nfire starts from dry lightning.\n\n* OUTFLOW WINDS...Instantaneous gusts as high as 40 mph. Gusts at\nthese speeds can be observed tens of miles away from the core of\nthe thunderstorm.\n\n* DRY AND UNSTABLE...Unstable conditions with elevated mixing\nheights may promote pyroconvective activity over ongoing fires.\n\n* IMPACTS...Conditions may be favorable for rapid fire spread\nwhich may threaten life and property. Thunderstorm outflow\nwinds may result in unanticipated erratic fire spread. High\ninstability may result in fire growth. Frequent lightning and\ncritically dry fuels may result in new fire starts.",
          "instruction": "A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions\nare either occurring now, or will shortly. A combination of the\nabove conditions can contribute to extreme fire behavior.",
          "response": "Prepare",
          "parameters": {
            "AWIPSidentifier": [

          "headline": "Beach Hazards Statement issued September 3 at 3:52AM EDT until September 3 at 10:00PM EDT by NWS Marquette MI",
          "description": "* WHAT...Dangerous swimming conditions are expected due to high\nwave action and strong rip currents.\n\n* WHERE...Marquette and Alger Counties.\n\n* WHEN...From 10 AM EDT this morning through this evening.\n\n* IMPACTS...High wave action and dangerous currents will lead to\nlife threatening swimming conditions. Waves in rapid\nsuccession can tire swimmers quickly.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Current related fatalities and rescues in\nthe past have occurred due to similar wave conditions at\nlocations listed below:\n\nFor Marquette County: Middle Bay north of Presque Isle and at\nLittle Presque Isle.\n\nFor Alger County: The Au Train River mouth at Au Train, the\nexposed regions of Grand Marais Harbor, and Pictured Rocks\nNational Lakeshore.",

          "headline": "Heat Advisory issued September 3 at 12:21AM PDT until September 3 at 6:00PM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA",
          "description": "* WHAT...Hot daytime conditions with high temperatures of 92 to 102\ndegrees common, and very warm overnight conditions.\n\n* WHERE...A portion of southwest California.\n\n* WHEN...Until 6 PM PDT this evening.\n\n* IMPACTS...There is a high risk for heat illness for sensitive\npopulations including the very young, the very old, those without\nair conditioning, and those active outdoors.",
          "instruction": "Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out of\nthe sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors.\n\nTo reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational Safety and\nHealth Administration recommends scheduling frequent rest breaks in\nshaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone overcome by heat\nshould be moved to a cool and shaded location. Heat stroke is an\nemergency! Call 9 1 1.",

          "event": "Rip Current Statement",
          "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
          "senderName": "NWS Melbourne FL",
          "headline": "Rip Current Statement issued September 3 at 1:42AM EDT until September 4 at 4:00AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL",
          "description": "* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents and rough surf.\n\n* WHERE...Coastal Volusia, Mainland Northern Brevard and\nNorthern Brevard Barrier Islands Counties.\n\n* WHEN...Through late tonight.\n\n* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away\nfrom shore into deeper water.",
          "instruction": "Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away\nfrom shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the\nsandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as jetties and\npiers. Heed the advice of lifeguards, beach patrol flags and\nsigns.\n\nEntering the surf is strongly discouraged. If caught in a rip\ncurrent, relax and float. Don't swim against the current. If\nable, swim in a direction following the shoreline. If unable to\nescape, face the shore and call or wave for help.",
          "response": "Avoid",
          "parameters": {

            ],

          "description": "...RED FLAG WARNING ISSUED FOR ABUNDANT LIGHTNING THROUGH\nWEDNESDAY EVENING FOR THE SOUTHERN DESCHUTES NATIONAL FOREST...\n\n* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 705 Southern Deschutes\nNational Forest.\n\n* TIMING...Until 8 PM PDT Wednesday.\n\n* IMPACTS...Any fire that develops will catch and spread\nquickly.           "instruction": "A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions\nare either occurring now, or will shortly. A combination of\nstrong winds, low relative humidity, and warm temperatures can\ncontribute to extreme fire behavior.",

          "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued September 2 at 12:45PM PDT by NWS Pendleton OR",
          "description": "The Washington State Department of Ecology and/or the Yakima\nRegional Clean Air Agency has issued an Air Quality Alert until\nfurther notice.\n\nAn Air Quality Alert has been issued for Kittitas and Yakima\nCounties until further notice due to current and expected wildfire\nsmoke from the Wildcat Fire. Particulate matter may reach Unhealthy\nlevels. When air quality is Unhealthy, everyone should reduce\nexposure. Limit time outside, avoid strenuous outdoor activity, and\nfollow tips for cleaner indoor air. Hot temperatures will increase\nthe risk of heat-related illnesses.           "description": "AQAHGX\n\nThe Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an\nOzone Action Day for the Houston, Galveston, and Brazoria area for\nWednesday, September 3, 2025.\n\nAtmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing\nhigh levels of ozone pollution in the Houston, Galveston, and\nsurrounding areas on Wednesday.           "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued September 2 at 9:13AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ",
          "description": "AQAPSR\n\nThe Arizona Department of Environmental Quality (ADEQ) has issued an\nOzone High Pollution Advisory for the Phoenix Metro Area through Wednesday.\n\nThis means that forecast weather conditions combined with existing\nozone levels are expected to result in local maximum 8-hour ozone\nconcentrations that pose a health risk. Adverse health effects\nincrease as air quality deteriorates.\n\nOzone is an air contaminant which can cause breathing difficulties\nfor children, older adults, as well as persons with respiratory\nproblems. A decrease in physical activity is recommended.\n\nYou are urged to car pool, telecommute or use mass transit.\nThe use of gasoline-powered equipment should be reduced or done late\nin the day.\n\nFor details on this High Pollution Advisory, visit the ADEQ internet\nsite at www.azdeq.gov/forecast/phoenix or call 602-771-2300.",
          "instruction": null,
